title: Recieved summons being sued by Asset Acceptance LLC. for $3086 plus interest and other. Can I settle out of court?
question: Action is a limited civil case for damages of $3086.03 plus interest at the rate of 10% per year from 9/29/2011 plus other the court deems just. The summons says I must respond in 30 days by proper legal form. Do I have to repond to the court? Can't I just settle with Asset Accceptance? Either way how do I do this? If I recieved this summons does it mean there is already a hearing set?
question_tags: LLC (limited liability company),Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Fees,Small claims court
answers:
Yes, you can certainly try to settle. I have three legal guides on Avvo on how to negotiate and settle a debt collection lawsuit. Linked below is Legal Guide #1. The deadlines and how to respond are explained in my blog, linked below, on making your next steps count. Your are correct, if you must respond by a particular deadline, file that with the Clerk of the Court and pay any filing fees due at that time. I explain all six options in the first video on my home page, which includes settlement as one option. If you call the collection attorney, they will discuss settlement terms, you should not try to call Asset's office directly.

Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com
Twitter: @RStempler

Understand that these debt collectors buy these debts for pennies on the dollar. Their business is literally filing lawsuits. You can settle, but as Mr. Chen states, you will likely need to file sn answer. If you don't, you risk a default, in which case you lost your bargaining chip.

That said, you would be well advised to speak with an attorney who handles debt collection cases. It would be money well spent.

Yes, you can settle out of court, either before or after you answer. It is possible to reach a settlement before you have to answer and pay the first appearance filing fee, but most practicing attorneys would suggest that you answer first and then negotiate a settlement.

For a limited jurisdiction case, there is no trial date set yet (unlike a small claims court case).

You can settle out of court before the hearing date and they can take the hearing off calander. An attorney might be able to save you a few hundred even after paying your attorney fees.
